fields.description:
It appears that something between bamboo and devenv.com is unhappy.  I had two plans using the devenv.com builder functionality from the nant plugin.  I upgraded from 2.0 to 2.0.1 this morning and could not restart the server (see the attached log).   To get around the problem, I had to remove the nant plugin from WEB-INF/lib, restart (which disabled the two plans because the builder was no longer available) and then resave the plans with some other builder.  I was then able to put the plugin back.  

Once I put the plugin back, I tried deleting all my devenv builder references and recreated them using the updated nant plugin in 2.0.1.  Once I referenced the new builder information and restarted the server, the same startup error returned.
fields.summary: Using devenv builder - server startup failure

fields.description:
I have a project with repository configured as follows: Build from CVS Branch/Tag Tag: PROJECT_0_1_7 Force Clean Builds: Checked The initial checkout and build works fine. Bamboo runs this: {noformat} Running CVS command: 'checkout -P -N -r PROJECT_0_1_7 Project '
... in: '/data/bamboo2/xml-data/build-dir/PROJECT-RELEASE'
... CVSROOT: '/data/cvs/cvs' {noformat} However, on subsequent builds: * force clean removes the checked out code as expected * then nothing gets checked out! {noformat} Running CVS command: 'checkout -P -N -r PROJECT_0_1_7 -D 2008-04-30 15:33:23 +1000 Project '
... in: '/data/bamboo2/xml-data/build-dir/PROJECT-RELEASE'
... CVSROOT: '/data/cvs/cvs' {noformat} The build fails because no files are there. I don't think the -D option makes any sense in this case.

User case:

2) click on "edit" for the group
3) unselect "tom"
4) click save
5) taken back to "manage group" section and there are still 2 users in that group

2) The table with the list of notifications seems to have a "random" order as well.  I'll have two plans with the same list of notifiers and they will be in a different order.

This lack of order for both just makes it harder to quickly scan the lists and use them.

fields.description:
This is closely related to BAM-2525, and might be considered another way of providing the same end-user functionality.

Essentially, instead of saying that I should load things from my underlying SCM system (P4, SVN, etc.), I say "use this other plan" (PlanA).

Then, when my child plan (PlanB), which uses this bootstrapping system kicks off, it pulls down a fork/copy of the entire state of the previous plan's state and uses that for the build area, rather than populating from the underlying SCM system.

I prefer this to BAM-2525, for the following reasons:
1) It allows me to support faster PlanA changes than PlanB changes.
For example, assume that PlanA is a build, PlanB is a quick test suite, and PlanC is a comprehensive test suite. I can do 10 PlanA builds, and 3 PlanB builds for 1 PlanC build. I really don't care about the PlanA artifacts that I'm not using for PlanB (and thus PlanC), and I'd prefer not to even keep them around.

2) It allows me to actually build PlanA faster
Again, consider a Build/Quick/Full pattern. In this case, I don't want to share the build area, because then I HAVE to block PlanA while PlanB and PlanC run. That's terrible if PlanA takes 5 minutes, PlanB takes 10 minutes, and PlanC takes 4 hours (not an uncommon case here). I'd much prefer to be able to keep PlanA chugging along and giving people build success notifications while everybody waits for the PlanC results (which are the super-slow ones that nobody wants to wait for just to find out if they've broken the build).

3) It supports multiple agents
If I share build area, under the current model, everything would have to be on the same build agent. That doesn't work for me in a multi-test scenario:
PlanA is my build
PlanB is test on Linux (depends on PlanA)
PlanC is test on Windows (also depends on PlanA)
PlanD is test on Solaris in London (also depends on PlanA)
PlanE is test on Solaris in New York (also depends on PlanA)

If I have to share a build area, I can't support this model.

Even without multiple independent builds dependent on the same source, I'd MUCH prefer to be able to allocate my agents by response time: allocate a 16-core machine to C++ builds where I need instantaneous developer response, and allocate slower machines to running tests where I don't need as fast a response.

In summary: Forking is better than sharing.

fields.description:
From BSP-749
{quote}
Imagine I have two projects or plans:
ProjA-Build
ProjA-Test

The two (in the case of devenv and NUnit) may even be using different builders, meaning that it's impossible or undesirable (due to timing) to have the testing project actually build things themselves.

What is the preferred approach to doing this without forcing a separate p4 sync and build? Ideally, what I'd like is to have the ProjA-Test base itself completely on the directory and data from ProjA-Build. Is that possible? Would I have to have artifacts and load the artifacts or something? (this would be potentially difficult with NUnit, which requires the DLLs coming from devenv.com)
{quote}
fields.summary: Ability to share working directory between different plans.

fields.description:
If I have local agents on the same machine as the Bamboo metadata server, then I can navigate the build working directory. This isn't true of remote agents, and I'd like it to be.

I can see the following scenarios:
- Remote agent launches an HTTP server on the filesystem which only the metadata server can connect to and passes through the resources. This would be an extremely quick, painless way to add this functionality.
- Or, it's all done over JMS
- I can give a network path (if the files are shared using NFS or CIFS) in the configuration of the remote agent indicating how its build working directory would appear to the metadata server, then the metadata server can read from that remote path to serve the resources.

I mention this highly because our plan on full Bamboo adoption is to ONLY have remote agents, and have the metadata server running on its own process.
fields.summary: Ability to see files on remote agents

fields.description: On JBAC2 there were over 50+GB of temporary files under /j2ee/domains/atlassian.com/jira2.bamboo/apache-tomcat-5.5.23/temp. They appear to be the results of builds from agents. We probably need to delete these files when they are no longer needed.
fields.summary: Remote agent artifacts result in temporary files on the server that are not removed

fields.description:
In bamboo you have three different options when starting up the standalone server.

1) Give 3 arguments and its sets it up nice for you (standard)
2) Give 1 argument - the location of the jetty.xml file to use to set it up
3) Give 0 Arguments - This Should find our default jetty.xml file and use that - but it doesn't work.  

Might be an idea to set it up to use the resource loader to find the jetty.xml file rather than hard-coding the location of the default file.  This will also make it easier for other people trying to set up their own custom config.
fields.summary: Starting Bamboo with no option doesn't work

fields.description:
Bamboo tries to save the external definition data along with the plan. And if the SVN external definition follows a nested path with several directories, e.g: third-party/b. Bamboo tries to save this path with the / and this throws an invalid XML character error.

This prevents users from editing a plan with SVN:Externals defined in Bamboo 2.0/beta or updating to Bamboo 2.0 from Bamboo 1.2.4
fields.summary: Can't upgrade to Bamboo 2.0 or save plan configuration, due to Bamboo trying to write invalid SVN external definition to XML

fields.description:
When upgrading from 1.2.x to 2.0 Bamboo reads in the allowed builds for a queue and coverts them into a capability/requirements match.

Currently however if you have a plan specifically assigned to multiple (but not all - not sure what would happen in this case) queues but not others, two sets of requirements are created, one for the first queue and one for the second.  This results in an inability for any agent to build the plan because no agent matches BOTH requirements.

See screen shot for an example.  In this case the build was assigned to both the Everthing Else Queue and the JIRA Plugins Queue, the resulting requirement should have been ALLOW_ANY_BUILDS|\QEverything Else Queue\E|\QJIRA Plugins Queue\E.

The other issue with this is it violates the restrictions on requirement keys and creates 2 with the same key (which causes other issues).
fields.summary: Upgrading 'allowed builds' to capability/requirements match doesn't work properly

fields.summary: Bamboo 2.0 war explodes to the root directory

fields.description:
Currently perforce will perform a sync on 2 occasions,
1. If the source directory is empty. or
2. If the vcs revision is null

This means that every time you create a plan on the same depot view it will do a full checkout (even though the source is there). This can be painful for large depots.

We may need to check this behaviour is logical (maybe it should only use -f for case 1. and not 2.) or add the option to turn off the -f all together.

Issue raised in support request: [BSP-724|https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-724|]
fields.summary: Add the ability to turn off the -f flag for perforce syncs

fields.description:
For many reasons, it's handy for developers to know information about how a Plan is setup and working.  Could the entire "Configuration" tab be made always viewable from the Plan summary page, but the "Edit Plan" button/link (available on each subtab), not be available unless one has Edit permissions.  

If the entire Configuration tab is not practical, then the build type, frequency, for a specific Plan is probably the most important info to share so people understand what the build is getting, when it should execute next, etc.   This would be pretty much the entire "Source Repository" configuration tab, but only the data.   It seems right now only those with Edit level permissions can see this information and I would like to share the information, but not give people the ability to edit.  

Thanks

fields.description:
Hi Andrew,

Can you please document the new mechanism for configuring the remote agent heartbeat interval?

It's set by:

# Adding -Dbamboo.agent.heartbeatInterval=_interval_in_seconds_ at the appropriate location in the Bamboo server's command line; or
# Adding <property name="bamboo.agent.heartbeatInterval">_interval_in_seconds_</property> at the appropriate location in bamboo.cfg.xml.

The server needs to be restarted to implement the change.

If neither of these mechanisms are used, the default heartbeat interval is 5 seconds.

Give me a shout if you need any more information, or if you'd like me to proof-read.

Cheers,
Adrian

fields.description:
When running a public continuous integration server, the potential risk is that a rogue build will interfere with 

# bamboo
# another project

While I suspect we could use remote agents to get around most of the risk of a plan interfering with bamboo; it does not help with preventing interference between projects.

A cunning plan that I had was to allow the bamboo server to sudo to a variety of different accounts (typically one user per project.

The launching the build would look something like 

{code}
sudo -u <project user> /home/bamboo/home/temp/launcher.sh
{code}

Then the entire build would run as that user, completely isolated from the rest of the system and other plans.


I've looked through the various plugins, and it doesn't appear I can write a plugin to intercept the build - and I don't want to have to write 4 plugins that pretty much replicate the existing builders (Ant / Maven / Maven2 / bash) - unless I can call them easily after I've sudoed - which I doubt.
fields.summary: Add the ability to run a plan as another user

fields.description: It would be neat if there was a way to re-order the builds in a build queue. Sometimes we have a jillion (literally, a jillion) builds queued up and we'd like to take one from the bottom and give it a higher priority right then and there.

fields.description: Should be able to have builds that are scheduled via a cron "build strategy" execute *only* if changes where found in the repository. This way you could ensure that builds start e.g. at the full hour only (8:00, 9:00 etc), so when you commit code you don't have to wonder (or bother to check...) if you just missed a build or how soon to expect feedback from Bamboo. This is even more important if builds are done even less frequently.
fields.summary: Conditional, cron-based scheduling

fields.description:
One of our customer reported this issue in  https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-661
{quote}  We use CVS for Source Code controll. To work consistent over all our supported platforms we use CVS on windows to checkout files with Unix Lineends. Bamboo seems to convert to Windows lineends when checking out sources. Is it possible to control this behaviour?{quote}
fields.summary: Investigate whether there is a way to control linends conversion when checking out from CVS

Currently, if the server throws an error the CVS build just hangs.

Bamboo should recover from such failures and alert user of the error returned from the server.

fields.description: I think some sort of free personal license for Bamboo would be great  Much like the upcoming JIRA and Confluence Personal Licenses.
fields.summary: Personal License

fields.description:
New Perforce Library Does not support perforce versions BEFORE 2005.1

In 2005.1 the following synonyms were created to run on the command line

synonymn           command
--------                    -------
changelist           change
changelists         changes
workspace          client
workspaces        clients

In 2001.1
	    #0 is now a synonym for #none when specifying (no) revisions.

We need to check where they get used, remove them, and retest.
fields.summary: Bamboo 2.0 does not support perforce versions BEFORE 2005.1

fields.description:
See my thread:

http://forums.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?threadID=24825&tstart=0

If I have much build plans the users will have hard work to get all artifacts (nightly builds).

We think a way to facilitate that.

The easiest way to implement it is list the artifacts dependent on any build plan.
But this suggestion is not very configurable... I can not create my packages of artifacts with my rules :/
My example:
Eclipse plug-in SPIDER package:
- has build plan for SPIDER core plug-in
- has build plan for SPIDER ui plug-in
- has build plan for SPIDER wizards plug-in
- has build plan for SPIDER doc

Eclipse plug-in SPIDER Template Editor package
- has build plan for SPIDER Template core plug-in
- has build plan for SPIDER Template ui plug-in

The implementation of a CRUD for package or artifact grouping is an option most powerful to do this.
fields.summary: Artifact grouping

fields.description:
We are using a build gate to build Clover. When this build passes, it triggers at least 5 other PLANS to be queued.

If however, during the build, someone makes a commit, then those builds later in the queue get this change.

Dependent PLANS should use the same REVISION_ID when updating from the repository  as the PLAN which caused them to be triggered.

The 'Master PLAN' could also take precedence in the queue if changes are made before the build PLAN chain has finished.
fields.summary: Ensure build consistency across child builds and their parent

fields.description:
A feature I feel is really missing from Bamboo is the ability to set Project level configuration and have the PLANs inherit these settings and override them if required.

This is similar to the way the FishEye Admin allows you to set repository defaults and have each repo override those specific to that repo.

Any 'global' configuration changes (e.g. svn repo changes, new build agents/requirements etc) can then be made quickly and easily in the one spot.
fields.summary: Project Level Configurations

fields.description:
"Enterprise IE 7" build #8 on jira2.bamboo.atlassian.com
Agent didn't send a heartbeat to the server within the timeout so the server thought that the agent went offline. The agent continued to run the build and re-established contact with the server. The agent was shown as inactive in the dashboard but in the detailed view it was shown as building the "Enterprise IE 7" build and was actively updating the server's build logs for that build.
fields.summary: Build continued after agent lost and recontacted server

fields.description:
Currently, there is no indication of which agent executed the Bamboo build on the dashboard - the only way to find this out, is to click through to the buildresultsummary page and view the agent that build the plan.

Perhaps we can integrate this into the build number, for eg: DEF-BUILD-12-Agent_On_Remote_Server ?

Raised due to BSP-661 -{quote}On the Dashboard in the "Current Activity" Tab is see on the right a
table that shows some results of builds. There It would be nice to see
on which (remote) Agent a build was running. There is not much space
to put this info in, but maybe it would be possible to integrate this
info into the buildnumber.

Another place where the info on which agent the build was executed
would make sense is the Project view in the "Completed Builds" Tab.

I know that I can see the info "Build on agent" when I look to the
"Build Results", but seeing this already in the overview would be
better.{quote}
fields.summary: The dashboard should give indication of which agent executed (or is executing) the Bamboo build.
Email Bamboo admins when builds start failing due to issues with the repository.

fields.description:
Probably due to the new use of rlog (which scans all file changes, not just those of files that exist on disk), Bamboo is listed changes for files that were added on branches.  CVS internally creates a changelog for these files on MAIN and shows them as "file FileName was initially added on branch branch-name" as revision 1.1, despite the file not existing on MAIN at rev 1.1.  (See http://build.limewire.org/bamboo/browse/LW-NIGHTLY-396/commit for an example).

This adds a lot of confusing clutter to changes from plans on MAIN, especially when a lot of unrelated work is being done on a branch.
fields.summary: File Added In Attic Changelog Shown For CVS Plans on MAIN

fields.description:
We have a plan that's set to build off the branch 'firewalled-magnets-v4-branch' (with the module 'limewire'). Bamboo seems to be listing the correct changes, but not actually updating the files. Looking at the one of the CVS/Entries files in the build-dir for the plan, it looks like Bamboo just didn't checkout the correct branch. The Entries is listed as if it were MAIN (no branch information included). fields.description:
There is a mechanism, provided by the ReturnUrlAware interface and the ReturnableRedirectResult class, used to "short-circuit" WebWork action processing, and allow Freemarker templates to specify the URL to be redirected to as the result of the following action.  The actual result of the action, and any action mappings defined, are completely ignored.

This goes against the design principles behind WebWork, makes debugging the non-obvious behaviour that results confusing (costing time and requiring effort), and limits application flexibility and the potential for re-use (again costing time and requiring effort).

See BAM-2404 for an example of a the kind of problem this causes.

A more appropriate solution would be to pass in the desired WebWork result (not the URL) as a parameter, and have the Action return this result once the Action has completed processing.  The action mapping would then map each result to the correct URL.  This way, the Action still has the final say over what the result is.
fields.summary: ReturnUrlAware/ReturnableRedirectResult should be removed

fields.description: This is especially so when you have polling strategy with a small polling interval.

fields.description:
If a Perforce command does not execute due to: 

Request too large (over 500000); see 'p4 help maxresults'.

This response is not caught as an error and is therefore parsed for the expected response, which can cause some unpredictable behaviour especially for the 'changes' command.  The perforce library should have this as one of the error messages it  'looks out for' and errors out appropriately.
fields.summary: Perforce library does not handle the error message "Request too large"
